column3: response

Most people in the past didn't die from heart disease because they didn't live long enough to develop it. Alexander Fleming developed Penicillin in 1928. It saved between 12-15% of soldiers' lives in World War II. The golden age is coming to an end. Antibiotic resistance causes superbugs that respond to two, one or even none of the hundred antibiotics we have. By 2050 it could claim 10 million lives, more than the population of New York City.

Early on many people did not die of heart disease or strokes or anything, they died because of infections. Most everybody that got injured eventually got an infection and died. In the early 1900s, Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin and that it would fight most bacterial infections. Pencil has saved many lives. However, it comes with its own set of problems. Over the years viruses have mutated and have become immune to many antibiotics they are called "superbugs". So we create stronger antibiotics and then the superbugs become even stronger. This goes back-and-forth until sometime in the future, the bacteria will win. Heavy use of antibiotics in livestock also increases our resistance to the very antibiotics that are supposed to help us.

In the old days, people didn't die of cancer or heart disease or other modern illnesses because they didn't live long enough. They died from being gored by an ox or mangled by a wagon accident and the resulting infection.  Then penicillin was discovered in 1927 and infections no longer killed people. But over time, bacteria have become resistant to penicillin and the derivatives that pharmaceutical companies research and develop. And the bacteria are evolving faster than the researchers can keep up with. So now, people are once again dying from infections for which we have no cure. And the pace is increasing. If we don't address the issue and stop over-using antibiotics by 2050, more people will die from infections than the entire population of NYC.

In the past people didn't die of the diseases that are common today.  They didn't live long enough to develop them.  They died of an injury or an infection.  That changed when antibiotics were discovered by Alexander Fleming.  Now infections that were once a death sentence were no longer that.  Now people are dying again because of antibiotic resistance.  For years we played a game of trying to find drugs to treat these diseases and fight the resistance.  It seems overwhelming to deal with antibiotic resistance but you have to keep taking steps to address it.

While antibiotics have been used to fight bacterial infections for 90 years, their effectiveness may be coming to an end. "Superbugs" are developing that are more resistant to traditional antibiotics.  If we want to maximize the effective ness of antibiotics we can do things like not eat meats or vegetables that have been treated with antibiotics.

Most people didn't live long enough to experience heart problems. When Penicillin was invented it helped save and extend lives. However resistance to the antibiotics is growing and there are now super bugs that barely respond to any antibiotics if they do actually respond. These can potentially wipe out most of the city of New York.

People in the past didn't die of cancer because they didn't live long enough to get it. Before antibiotics, people would die quickly of infection. The invention of penicillin has saved many lives, including 12-15% of the allies in WW1. Now, penicillin is overused, creating resistant bacteria known as superbugs. People should try to limit antibiotic use.

few decades back, people died of various reasons but not of cancer or heart disease. later antibiotics were found to cure the infections. by then the virus or bacterial agents reacted to the antibiotics and the diseases were cured. but now the foreign particles developed resistance to the antibiotics and day by day the medicines are becoming helpless and new diseases are being diagnosed.so, if we take concern for these changes like buying chicken or fruit raised with antibiotic use we could slow down the arrival of the post-antibiotic world.so, we have to take the responsibility for the climate change and other perspectives affecting the environment

Through history, most people didn't die of cancer or hear disease, the lifestyle diseases that are common in the Western world today. This is mostly because people didn't live long enough to develop them. They died of injuries -- being gored by an ox, shot on a battlefield, crushed in one of the new factories of the Industrial revolution -- and most of the time from infection, which followed those injuries.

That changed when antibiotics were discovered. In 1928 Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin, a drug still used today to fight bacterial infections.

...
For 70 years, we played a game of leapfrog-- out drug and their resistance, and then another drugs, and then resistance again -- and now the game is ending, Bacteria develop resistance so quickly that pharameutical companies have decided making antibiotics is not in their best interest


If we did those things, we could slow down the arrival of the post-antibotic world.

Up until recent history most human deaths weren't from causes that are common today. They mainly died from physical injury, mostly from infection caused by them. Upon the discovery of antibiotics in the 1920s this all changed. For a while this worked incredibly well. Now things are looking down. The bugs that cause these infections are becoming more and more resistant to antibiotics. We've been playing a game of "leapfrog" ever since the discovery of antibiotics. We'd find an antibiotic that would work, the bacteria would evolve so that it was resistant to it, then we'd discover a way to fight the resistant bacteria, rinse and repeat. Projected statistics say that by the year 2050 people will die at a rate of 10 million per year due to our inability to fight bacterial infections. That is more people than the current population of New York. There are ways we could slow this down, but it seems inevitable.

People didn't use to die of cancer and heart disease like today because they never lived long enough to get it. People used to die on accidents at work or infections that developed after injuries. This all change when penicillin was introduced to people. Penicillin was used as an antibiotic that cured infections that used to be a death sentence in a matter of days. It was estimated that penicillin saved around 12-15 percent of allied soldiers in the war. Our golden age of antibiotics is coming to a close because of superbugs. Superbugs were formed because of antibiotics making them resistant to them over time. We are now cutting back on antibiotics because the more we use them the stronger the superbugs become and the less likelihood of being able to treat infections and diseases. We should all resist the temptation of using antibiotics for certain infections to delay the end of antibiotics.

Then in 1928, when antibiotics were made by Alexander fleeing to fight bacterial infections. The drug has saved around 15% of allied forces lives during world war II, but today people are dying from infections again due to antibiotic resistance. For 70 years, we played a game of leapfrog, our drug and their resistance, repeat over and over. That too comes a end, as bacteria now develop resistance quickly and people can't make new antibiotics fast enough to fight against them effectively. We could only do things to slow down the process of the bacteria.

People died more often from injury, crushing, or infection. Until 1928, when Alexander created the antiobiotic to fight infections. 15% of troops were saved by antiobiotics during WWII. This too, however, comes to an end. It was a game of leapfrog, with bacteria progressing beyond antiobiotics and us catching up to the bacteria. Now we have antiobiotic-resistant bacteria.

People didn't die of cancer because they never lived long enough to get it. Before the invention of penicillin, people would succumb to those life-threatening diseases in matter of days. However, our continued use of penicillin has made something known as super bugs which have become resistant to the effects of antibiotics. Try to avoid the use of antibiotics.

The ways that people die nowadays are not the same as most people died for most of human history.  In the past, most people died from physical injuries they sustained and the subsequent infections that resulted from those injuries.  However, this changed in the 1920s with the discovery of antibiotics.  Antibiotics allowed us to treat infections and kill the associated bacteria.  However, our ability to do this is under threat.  Since the discovery of antibiotics, we've been playing a proverbial game of leap-frog with bacteria.  We'd develop an antibiotic to kill bacteria, then that bacteria would evolve to become resistant to the antibiotic, and then we'd develop a new antibiotic to kill the evolved bacteria.  But this will only go on for so long.  It's projected that by 2050, 10 million people per year will die from bacterial infections that are resistant to antibiotics.  That's more than the current population of New York.  There are ways that we could slow this phenomenon down, but even so, it seems inevitable.

In the olden days, people wouldn't die of cancer or heart disease like we do today, mostly because they didn't live long enough to develop those diseases. They would die by being crushed in industrial accidents in one of the few factories around at that time, or mauled to death by an ox or from injury or infection. Since the development of antibiotics in 1928, people have lived a lot longer becuase we could treat those infections with this new regimen. 12-15% of allied soldiers were estimated to be saved from infection using antibiotics. The leading cause of death throughout history has primarily been due to injuries and infection. While this went away after antibiotics were invented, deaths from infection are on the rise because bacteria continue to evolve to combat the vaccines we develop. Now bacteria evolve so quickly that it isn't financially worth it to companies to keep developing new strains of antibiotics.

Historically, humans did not live long enough to die from things like cancer, heart failure, etc. Many people died after receiving injuries - whether animal wounds from hunting, or being crushed by rocks, or war wounds, or factory accidents - and the infections that followed those injuries.
But after penicillin was discovered in the early 20th century by Mr. Fleming, infections became possible to treat. Infections that once killed people, could now be cured within days, and easily. This resulted in a dramatic number of lives saved during World War I; somewhere between 10-15% of Allied forces by some estimates. Death from infections dropped dramatically everywhere.
But this is now changing. Bacteria evolve and develop resistances to antibiotic drugs, and for decades companies were constantly developing new drugs to kill bacteria as they became resistant to old ones. And now there are "superbugs" - types of bacteria that are immune to most, if not all, available antibiotics. And pharmaceutical companies are finding it too hard to develop new drugs. Already some 700,000 peopel a year are dying by infections worldwide, and if a solution isn't found by 2050 that number could rise to 10,000,000 a year - about the population of NYC.
There may come a day when only one or two, or no drugs at work on a given infection. And one way to combat this is by reducing our antibiotic use. Don't prescribe antibiotics to common childhood illnesses like earaches if we are not certain it is the right drug, don't buy or eat foods raised with animal treated with antibiotics, and other similar actions.

Back then, people didn't die from cancer or heart disease, they didn't live long enough to experience these problems as they were killed by animals, died in the war, or were killed in factory jobs. When antibiotics came into the picture, this led to saving millions of lives, especially for the allied forces in WWII. This penicillin is even used today. But now people have begun to die again because of resistance to antibiotics. This includes MRSA and many other strains of bacterium. The weaker organism dies off, but the survivors come back even stronger than before leading to a back and forth between the two until we reach our inevitable outcome in a post-antibiotic world. Even pharmaceuticals companies want no stake in this losing war.

People in the past died of different things. Most of the time they died from injury and infection. In the early 1900s this changed dramatically with the invention of new medicines and techniques. But now theres antibiotic resistant bacteria, which is really dangerous. Lots more people could die in the future if we don't figure it out. We should probably stop overusing antibiotics.

Through history people died for lots of reasons, but then Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin, which helped fight bacterial infections. The problem is now bacteria are evolving to beat antibiotics and people are dying from less treatable infections. You can take small steps, the way one does for the environment by using a fluorescent light bulb, to fight the rise of the superbugs by not using antibiotics when unnecessary.

The discovery of penicillin by Alexander Flemming changed the world and the way we treat infections. Penicillin is still used today as an antibiotic and prompted the development of hundreds more. Flemming's discovery aided in World War II, reducing Allied deaths by 10-15%. Antibiotics have also allowed people to live far longer than in the past. People used to die from injury, or infection, but due to this prolonged longevity, we are now dying from lifestyle diseases like heart disease.

The current number of worldwide deaths due to infection is around 700,000 and is actually anticipated to only rise. By 2050, the estimated toll will be around 10 million. Why? Antibiotic resistance or the rise in "superbugs" renders current antibiotics useless and allows bacteria to thrive. The use of antibiotics is like a game of leapfrog; as we develop new antibiotics, the bacteria become resistant, so we develop new drugs, and so on. These bacteria will only continue to develop resistance against antibiotics if we continue to overuse antibiotics. We need to cut back on our use of antibiotics for every little ailment, or soon this problem will be out of control.

Throughout most of human history, people did not typically die from heart disease or cancers. The died young from gun shot wounds, factory accidents, falling off a horse, or (most of the time) from infections, as a result of those injuries. 

Death by infection forever changed in the 1920's when antibiotics were discovered. Millions of lives have been saved in the decades since and people are living longer lives. But antibiotic resistance is gaining considerable ground and we are becoming more at risk of death by bacteria. "Superbugs" have been getting worse and killing many people. The problem is expected to worsen. Currently in the U.S. and Europe, about 50,000 people die a year from infections that cannot be treated. That number is expected to rise to 10 million a year by 2050, unless we can do something to stop it.

Tiny steps can be taken now to help stave off disaster later, like not taking unnecessary antibiotics or not consuming meats raised on antibiotics.

Antibiotics were a miracle that revolutionized the treatment of different infections.  Their use has saved countless millions of lives in the last 100 or so years.  However, we've overused antibiotics, and now many bacteria have evolved or adapted to be resistant to their use.  We're creating new super antibiotics, but we also need to drastically cut the use of older antibiotics.

Overuse of antibiotics causes this. The best thing people can do to help is not use antibiotics unless it is neccessary.

Unfortunately the overuse of antibiotics has lead to bacteria become more and more resistant to them. Unless we find a way to fix this it could mean up to 10 million deaths in 2050 because of what mainly is overuse of antibiotics causing these resistant strains of bacteria.

Throughout history most people did not die from the common diseases seen today such as heart disease and cancer. many did not live long enough to develop these illnesses because they died in war, in accidents, or from more common infections. Once we discovered penicillin and other antibiotics, less people died from these infections. However, the more we use antibiotics, the more antibiotic resistant diseases show up. Scientists estimate that these diseases could cause up to 10 million annual deaths by 2050 if we do not do something about it soon.

before the advent of antibiotics people used to die from injuries caused by accidents gunshot wounds etc. Since antibiotics were discovered many lives have been saved including thousands on the battlefields. Thanks to advances in medicine and science we're living longer today than we ever have before.  Some of the greatest threats to our survival hundreds of years ago are trivial in the modern era of medicine and antibiotics, but it's this same triumph of modern medicine that may take us back to suffering from those problems once again.

As we've gotten more and more accustomed to using antibiotics as our first line of defense against bacteria and infections, so too have those ailments gotten more accustomed to fighting back.  We are seeing an ever-growing number of cases in which bacteria is able to resist everything we throw at it, and this is leading to more and more people losing their lives to things that many assumed we had conquered.  Current projections for the impact of this issue are not looking optimistic, but if we act now and start taking precautions like avoiding the overuse of antibiotics when they aren't necessary we may be able to slow down this issue until we can make another breakthrough to keep the bacteria at bay.

For much of recorded history people didn't die of things like cancer or heart disease.  Most people died from accidents or injuries incurred while doing things like hunting, working outside, or factory work; and the subsequent infections incurred from such accidents.  That all changed in the 1920's with the discovery of pencillin and the evolution of antibiotic drugs.  Now, infectious bacteria are becoming antibiotic resistant though.  Currently thousands of people die each year from infections that are immune to treatment by antibiotics.  That is expected to rise to millions of people by the year 2050.

Alexander Fleming discovered anitibotics which helped reduced numerous deaths throughout the ages due to infection. Although anitibiotics have saved millions of lives, infections are spreading because the bacteria are becoming resistant due to evolution. It is imperative to use antibiotics only when necessary.
We could die from anti-bacterial resistance. If we don't reduce the problem nearly 10 million people may die by 2050.

For most of history, we have focused on treating disease with anitbiotics.  But thru time, the antibiotics have evolved and our original treatments are no longer effective.  We need to stop immediately prescribing antibiotics and let our bodies fight it initially

The overuse of antibiotics has created a potential problem. Infections are a relatively new problem in human history. War and death by accident or injuries accounted for a greater number of deaths. 

People are now becoming immune/resistant to the antibiotics. 'Superbugs' is a potential rising epidemic with the possibility that millions who could die due to being immune to treatment.

Thanks to  Alexander Fleming , the inventor of penicillin,  millions of people survive being infected by bacteria. Unfortunately, bacteria are a constantly adapting entity and inevitability will be penicillin resistant. Science predicts in 2050 700,000 people will die due to these mutated bacteria nicknamed 'super bugs.'  Currently, scientist and medical professions all utilizing special lights to kill these bacteria. People can help combat super bugs by only taking antibiotics when they are necessary.

Even though only 700,000 people die from infections, that number is supposed to rise to 10,000,000 by 2050. The reason for the dramatic increase is bacteria's ability to evolve and become resistant to the current antibodies we have currently. These super bugs are resistant to the antibodies and render them useless. The is why it is important it use antibodies only when absolutely necessary.

The creation of antibiotics helped reduce the amount of infection related deaths.  This came with a drawback, however.  Bacteria is becoming resistant to antibiotics, and at this rate 10 million will die by 2050 from antibiotic resistant bacteria.

Over the years people have been able to survive illnesses due to the medicine penicillin but, due to disease-causing bacteria gaining resistance, that soon may not be enough anymore. By 2050, death from infectious diseases may jump to 10,000,000 (from the current 700,000) by 2050. The best way to slow down this resistance is by encouraging everyone to only resort to antibiotics when needed and to practice prevention.

Throughout history, mankind has been susceptible to injury and death by misadventure, occupational hazards, and a host of infections and diseases. Many people never reached old age due to death from common sicknesses. Once Fleming's invention of antibiotics were introduced, illnesses and injuries that would have killed before were now able to be treated. However, as time has progressed, our bodies have adapted and so have the diseases. We are starting to see extensive evidence of drug-resistant bugs, which could be the result of overuse of antibiotics. If something does not change in the way we prescribe and use these drugs, it is estimated that by the year 2050, as many as 10 million people a year could die to drug-resistant illnesses. That's the equivalent of the population of New York City.

In earlier times people would die from infections and injuries (that led to infections), but the rise of antibiotics drastically reduced the rate of death. Unfortunately, overuse of these antibiotics has caused bacteria to become resistant to their effects (super resistant) and if we don't control it then up to 10 million people could die in 2050 as a result of these resistant strains of bacteria which no longer respond to the typically given antibiotics.

Antibiotics, also known as antibacterials, are medications that destroy or slow down the growth of bacteria. They include a range of powerful drugs and are used to treat diseases caused by bacteria. Antibiotics cannot treat viral infections, such as cold, flu.

Thanks to achievements in medicine and antibiotics, people are living longer today than in the past.  The drawback to this, however, is that bacteria is becoming resistant to antibiotics, making them stronger, and creating a potential future threat that could take us back to the same historical level of potential danger.  Also, aging allows other things, such as cancer, to become more prevalent, since people are now able to live longer, making the chances of such things increase.

After Alexander Flemings' invention of penicillin, infections went down. However, these bacteria are evolving and are learning how to resist these antibiotics. There are about 700,000 deaths from infection, but this number will jump to 10,000,000 by 2050 due to antibiotics being much less effective due to overuse. Florescent light treatment is an alternative to defeating these bacteria.

Over the years since the 1900s, deaths due to infections has significantly decreased due to antibiotics. Unfortunately because of how often they are prescribed there are now "super" bacteria that are resistant to the antibiotics. If this problem isn't solved there will be about 10 million deaths by 2050.

As humans we have always been susceptible to infection and disease.  The discovery of antibiotics has helped save millions from infections that would have killed us in the past.  Unfortunately, we began taking antibiotics for minor infections that our bodies were capable of healing on their own.  This practice has created new antibiotic resistant diseases. Creating new super strength antibiotics to combat these diseases is not enough, we also have to stop prescribing antibiotics for small infections and allow our bodies to once again fight them on their own.  If we do not act immediately it is estimated that by 2050 nearly 10 million people per year will die from drug resistant infections.

Antibiotics have been used historically to treat infections and have worked well. However, more people are prescribing antibiotics for minor infections that the body can take care of by itself, which in turn, is creating more antibiotic resistant infections. If this trend continues, more and more infections are gonna be unable to be cured by regular antibiotics, and upwards of 10 million people a year are going to die from these super-infections that we've created.

Before the invention of penicillin and other antibiotics that followed, a human's life expectancy was often much shorter. It was uncommon for people to die from things like heart disease because most people would not live that long. Instead, more common but today less deadly ailments could be far worse without a method of treatment. On top of that, germ theory was not well understood for much of human history, and that made preventive measures impossible.

Today people generally don't need to fear most bacterial infections. However, many bacteria have begun to adapt to our poisons. If we don't move on the issue of antibiotic-resistance, we may well find ourselves returning to a period of much shorter life expectancies
